remarks.p: The OSCAL Control Catalog format can be used to describe a collection of security controls and related sub-controls, along with a variety of control metadata. The root of the Control Catalog format is catalog.
An XML Schema is provided for the OSCAL Catalog XML model.

define-assembly.name: metadata
define-assembly.description: Information describing the publication or availability of this document

define-field.name: publication-date
define-field.description: The official date of publication

define-assembly.name: party
define-assembly.description: A responsible entity, either singular (an organization or person) or collective (multiple persons)

remarks.p: As contents one of org or person is required, or both; there may be only one org, but many persons.

Note that persons can also be indicated with organizational affiliations by using orgname inside person. Contact information in that case belongs to the person, not the organization: use org when an organization as such serves as a documented party.

define-assembly.name: person
define-assembly.description: A person, with contact information

define-assembly.name: org
define-assembly.description: An organization or legal entity (not a person), with contact information

define-field.name: person-id
define-field.description: An identifier for a person (such as an ORCID) using a designated scheme.

define-field.name: org-id
define-field.description: An identifier for an organization using a designated scheme.

define-field.name: person-name
define-field.description: Full (legal) name of an individual

define-field.name: org-name
define-field.description: Full (legal) name of an organization

remarks.p: Only when this element is used directly within org can it be accepted of the name of the thing to which it is attached. This element may also be used directly on person to name an affiliated organization.

href can be used to provide external links or internal links to other elements. The sibling org-id element (similarly for affiliated organizations) can also be used to link (for example to organizations listed elsewhere as parties.)

define-field.name: short-name
define-field.description: A common name, short name or acronym

remarks.p: This element is not expected to be used to identify individual persons, but rather an organization or system.

define-assembly.name: address
define-assembly.description: A postal address

define-field.name: addr-line
define-field.description: A single line of an address

define-field.name: city
define-field.description: City, town or geographical region for mailing address

define-field.name: state
define-field.description: State, province or analogous geographical region for mailing address

define-field.name: postal-code
define-field.description: Postal or ZIP code for mailing address

define-field.name: country
define-field.description: Country for mailing address

define-field.name: email
define-field.description: Email address

define-field.name: phone
define-field.description: Contact number by telephone

define-field.name: url
define-field.description: URL for web site or Internet presence

define-assembly.name: role
define-assembly.description: Defining a role to be assigned to a party or agent

remarks.p: Permissible values to be determined closer to the application (e.g. by a receiving authority).

define-assembly.name: extra-meta
define-assembly.description: Container for (system-defined) metadata

define-assembly.name: meta-group
define-assembly.description: Custom- or application-defined annotated metadata.

define-field.name: meta
define-field.description: Any customized or specialized metadata value.

define-flag.name: term
define-flag.description: A classification (according to any schema or taxonomy) of a metadata value or set of values.

define-flag.name: role-id
define-flag.description: References a role element defined in metadata.

define-assembly.name: resource
define-assembly.description: A resource to inform or authenticate the present document, or to supplement it as an attachment

remarks.p: This element is used in two ways. In document metadata, it may describe and point to a mirror or other (authoritative or informative) copy of a document, or of a resouce helpful (necessary) for interpreting it, such as its metaschema or documentation. It may offer a (persistent) link to a best available version, or to an outdated version, as indicated by its rel.
In back matter or within sections, a resource may be an attachment or any external document.
The rel flag should be used to indicate the relation of the resource to the document referencing it, such as catalog, baseline, metaschema or attachment.

define-field.name: author
define-field.description: A named author

remarks.p: Note this information may be duplicative of information given in a party element with appropriate role-id flags, along with more a more complete structured listing. This element provides a value for display as well as an additional point of comparison.

define-field.name: doc-id
define-field.description: Any sort of document identifier, name, code, path or other indicator of where and how this document may be located, compared or validated. Given appropriate qualification via its type and rel, this value may point to the same or another version of the document.

remarks.p: Flags rel and type can qualify the kind and use of document identifier, in particular whether the value is to be attributed to the given instance, or to another instance, source or resource.
Specific usage rules, nomenclatures and recognized file types e.g. DOIs, CMS locators, etc etc., may be defined at application level. The value of this field may also be a hash or check sum.

define-flag.name: type
define-flag.description: Indicating the type of identifier or other data item.

remarks.p: Generally, this flag is used to relate to schemes and taxonomies defined outside the OSCAL application in some public form; i.e. they can be looked up.

define-assembly.name: notes
define-assembly.description: Any notes with further information

define-assembly.name: hlink
define-assembly.description: A pointer to an external document with optional hash for verification

remarks.p: This is different from unstructured link, which makes no provision for a hash or formal title. It is also different from the element of the same name once proposed for HTML.

define-field.name: hash
define-field.description: A document hash or other value subject to cryptographic authentication

remarks.p: When appearing as part of a resource (data object), the hash should apply to the referenced object.

define-flag.name: algorithm
define-flag.description: Method by which a hash is derived

remarks.p: One of the following is recognized: MD5, SHA-1, SHA-224, SHA-256, SHA-384, SHA-512, RIPEMD-160. See XML Security Algorithm Cross-Reference (W3C, April 2013) for more information.

define-flag.name: href
define-flag.description: A relative or absolute URI indicating a resource available on the Internet.

define-flag.name: media-type
define-flag.description: Describes the media or MIME type of a linked resource

define-assembly.name: description
define-assembly.description: A free-text description of the system.

define-field.name: version
define-field.description: Version information

remarks.p: The syntax may be validated in back. The date given should presumably be the same as the (human-readable) date given above it (and such a discrepancy is also be detectable).

define-field.name: format
define-field.description: For use when no mime-type is available or additional information is required.

define-flag.name: filename
define-flag.description: Name of the file before it was converted to Base-64. This is the name that will be assigned to the file when converted back to binary.

define-assembly.name: ref-list
define-assembly.description: A list of references to external resources. This object may be nested for reference lists composed of reference lists.

define-assembly.name: ref
define-assembly.description: A reference, with one or more citations to standards, related documents, or other resources

define-field.name: citation
define-field.description: Citation of a resource

remarks.p: Semantics of any contents within citation are implicit, not encoded. To mitigate problems establishin matches with bibliograpical databases, it is recommended a canonical identifier such as a DOI be provided for any citation.

define-field.name: link
define-field.description: A line or paragraph with a hypertext link

remarks.p: Works like an HTML anchor (a) except this is a line-oriented (block) element.

define-assembly.name: catalog
define-assembly.description: A collection of controls

remarks.p: Catalogs may use section to subdivide the textual contents of a catalog.

example.description: A small catalog with a single control

define-assembly.name: back
define-assembly.description: References, resources and attachments

define-assembly.name: section
define-assembly.description: Allows the inclusion of prose content within a Catalog.

define-assembly.name: group
define-assembly.description: A group of controls, or of groups of controls.

remarks.p: Catalogs can use groups to provide collections of related controls or Control Groups. A group may have its own properties, statements, parameters, and references, which are inherited by all members of that group. Unlike a section, a group may not contain arbitrary prose directly, only inside its part or control components.

define-assembly.name: control
define-assembly.description: A structured information object representing a security or privacy control. Each security or privacy control within the Catalog is defined by a distinct control instance.

remarks.p: Controls may be grouped using group, and controls may be partitioned using part or enhanced using subcontrol.

define-assembly.name: subcontrol
define-assembly.description: A control extension or enhancement

define-field.name: title
define-field.description: A title for display and navigation, exclusive of more specific properties

define-field.name: prop
define-field.description: A value with a name, attributed to the containing control, subcontrol, part, or group.

remarks.p: Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, with and among control objects (controls, parts, and extensions), for any purpose useful to an application or implementation of those controls. Typically, properties will be used to sort, select, order, and arrange controls or relate them to one another or to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities.
The value of a property is a simple scalar value or list of values.
The lexical composition of properties may be constrained by declarations including matching to regular expressions or by declaring a known datatype.

Because properties are often used as selectors or identifiers for OSCAL operations, their values can be expected frequently to be normalized (e.g., with respect to whitespace) in use; however, this is application defined.

For singletons (that is, the only element among siblings with its class), properties are especially useful as proxies (unique identifiers) for their controls, such that controls may be returned one for one on queries for properties (name and value). The robustness of such queries can be ensured by appropriate property declarations (as singletons and as identifiers); cf declare-prop in the declarations model (which also supports other constraints over property values).

define-assembly.name: param
define-assembly.description: Parameters provide a mechanism for the dynamic assignment of value(s) in a control.

remarks.p: In a catalog, a parameter is typically used as a placeholder for the future assignment of a parameter value, although the OSCAL model allows for the direct assignment of a value if desired by the control author. The value may be optionally used to specify one or more values. If no value is provided, then it is expected that the value will be provided at the Profile or Implementation layer.

A parameter can include a variety of metadata options that support the future solicitation of one or more values. A label provides a textual placeholder that can be used in a tool to solicit parameter value input, or to display in catalog documentation. The desc provides a short description of what the parameter is used for, which can be used in tooling to help a user understand how to use the parameter. A constraint can be used to provide criteria for the allowed values. A guideline provides a recommendation for the use of a parameter.

field.description: A short name for the parameter.

remarks.p: The label value should be suitable for inline display in a rendered catalog.

fields.description: A short summary of the parameter's intended use.

remarks.p: A label is optional, but should be provided unless a select (selection) is provided.

fields.description: A rule describing the permissible parameter values.

remarks.p: Currently, OSCAL does not standardize any formal rules language for value constraints. A test option may be used to specify a formal rule that may be automatically used if recognized by an OSCAL tool. Further development is needed to support the declaration of a rule language and value.

assemblies.description: Additional recommendations for the use of the parameter, or around what values should be provided.

field.description: A recommended parameter value or set of values.

remarks.p: A value provided in a catalog can be redefined at any higher layer of OSCAL (e.g., Profile).

assembly.description: A set of parameter value choices, that may be picked from to set the parameter value.

define-field.name: label
define-field.description: A placeholder for a missing value, in display.

define-field.name: desc
define-field.description: Indicates and explains the purpose and use of a parameter

define-field.name: constraint
define-field.description: A formal or informal expression of a constraint or test

define-assembly.name: guideline
define-assembly.description: A prose statement that provides a recommendation for the use of a parameter.

define-field.name: value
define-field.description: Indicates a permissible value for a parameter or property

remarks.p: In a declaration, value will commonly be given in groups, indicating a set of enumerated permissible values (i.e., for an element to be valid to a value constraint, it must equal one of the given values).

In a parameter, a value represents a value assignment to the parameter, overriding any value given at the point of insertion. When parameters are provided in OSCAL profiles, their values will override any values assigned lower down the stack.

define-assembly.name: select
define-assembly.description: Presenting a choice among alternatives

define-field.name: choice
define-field.description: A value selection among several such options

define-assembly.name: part
define-assembly.description: A partition or component of a control, subcontrol or part

remarks.p: Like properties (prop) and parameters (param), parts can be distinguished from other elements within their controls by their assigned class, such that they may be subjected to declarations logic using these values as bindings (and thereby getting open-ended extensibility).

An assigned class may frequently provide for a header in display, such that part [@class='objectives'] is displayed under a header Objectives, etc. Parts may also however have their own titles (title elements).

Many parts are logical partitions or sections for prose. Other parts may be more formally constructed out of properties (prop elements) and/or their own parts. Such structured objects may, at the extreme, function virtually as control extensions or subcontrol-like objects (enhancements).
No mechanism is proposed to ensure that id values do not collide across different catalogs. Use profiling without merge to detect such clashes.

define-flag.name: class
define-flag.description: Identifies the property or object within the control; a semantic hint

remarks.p: Overloading this attribute with more than one value is permitted, but not recommended.

define-flag.name: test
define-flag.description: A formal (executable) expression of a constraint

define-flag.name: how-many
define-flag.description: When selecting, a requirement such as one or more

define-flag.name: model-version
define-flag.description: Declares a major/minor version for this metaschema
